title: Applications of Integration
description: The capstone applications unit. Students use definite integrals to solve accumulated-quantity problems: finding the average value of a function, analyzing motion via velocity/acceleration integrals and the net change theorem, computing areas between curves, and determining volumes of solids with known cross-sections or generated by revolution (disk/washer methods). Weekly rhythm includes FRQ-style integration application sets mirroring AP exam format.
goals: Compute the average value of a function on an interval using f_avg = (1/(b-a))∫ₐᵇ f(x) dx and interpret it geometrically.
Use integrals of velocity and acceleration to determine displacement, total distance traveled, and position functions.
Apply the net change theorem to interpret ∫ₐᵇ f'(x) dx as the accumulated change f(b) - f(a) in applied contexts.
Set up and evaluate integrals for the area between two curves, including finding intersection points and integrating with respect to y when appropriate.
Calculate volumes of solids with known cross-sections (squares, semicircles, equilateral triangles) perpendicular to an axis.
Compute volumes of solids of revolution using the disk and washer methods, including revolution around non-axis lines.
instructionalStrategy: Gradual release: concept-intro → I Do → concept-check → We Do → check-in → You Do → mastery-check
AI uses scaffold array as scope and worked-example bank; AI makes all instructional decisions
Build from single-integral applications (average value, net change) before multi-step geometric applications (area, volume)
Emphasize setup over computation — correctly identifying integrand, bounds, and orientation is the core AP skill
Weekly FRQ-style integration application set for AP exam preparation
Spiral prior: antiderivative techniques from Units 6-7, Fundamental Theorem from Unit 6

scaffold.title: Average Value of a Function
scaffold.content: The average value of a continuous function on [a, b] generalizes the arithmetic average to continuous data. Instead of summing finitely many values and dividing by n, we integrate over the interval and divide by its length. The Mean Value Theorem for Integrals guarantees that the function actually attains its average value at least once.
keyPoints: Average value formula: f_avg = (1/(b-a)) ∫ₐᵇ f(x) dx
Geometric interpretation: f_avg is the height of the rectangle with base (b-a) whose area equals the area under f on [a, b]
MVT for Integrals: if f is continuous on [a, b], there exists c in (a, b) such that f(c) = f_avg = (1/(b-a)) ∫ₐᵇ f(x) dx
On the AP exam: always state the formula, show the integral setup, and interpret the result in context
Units: f_avg has the same units as f(x). If f is in gallons/minute, the average value is in gallons/minute.
Common error: forgetting the 1/(b-a) factor — the integral alone gives total accumulated quantity, not the average

scaffold.title: Average Value of a Function — Worked Examples

examples.problem: Find the average value of f(x) = x² + 1 on [0, 3].
examples.solution: f_avg = (1/(3-0)) ∫₀³ (x² + 1) dx = (1/3)[x³/3 + x]₀³ = (1/3)[(27/3 + 3) - 0] = (1/3)(9 + 3) = (1/3)(12) = 4. The average value is 4. Geometrically, the rectangle with height 4 and base 3 has the same area (12) as the region under f on [0, 3].

examples.problem: The temperature in a greenhouse is modeled by T(t) = 70 + 8sin(πt/12) degrees Fahrenheit, where t is hours after midnight. Find the average temperature from 6 AM to 6 PM (t = 6 to t = 18).

scaffold.title: Motion via Integrals & Net Change Theorem
scaffold.content: Integration reverses differentiation, so integrating a rate of change recovers the net change in the original quantity. For motion: integrating velocity gives displacement, and integrating the absolute value of velocity gives total distance. The net change theorem unifies all rate-of-change-to-accumulated-change problems.
keyPoints: Displacement = ∫ₐᵇ v(t) dt (net change in position; can be positive, negative, or zero)
Total distance traveled = ∫ₐᵇ |v(t)| dt (always non-negative; accounts for direction changes)
To compute ∫|v(t)| dt: find where v(t) = 0 (direction changes), split the integral, negate on intervals where v < 0
Position from velocity: s(t) = s(a) + ∫ₐᵗ v(u) du
Net change theorem: ∫ₐᵇ f'(x) dx = f(b) - f(a). The integral of a rate gives the net accumulated change.
Context examples: ∫ rate of water flow = net change in volume; ∫ marginal cost = change in total cost
Speed = |v(t)|. A particle speeds up when v and a have the same sign; slows down when they have opposite signs.

scaffold.title: Motion via Integrals & Net Change — Worked Examples

examples.problem: A particle moves along the x-axis with velocity v(t) = t² - 4t + 3 for 0 ≤ t ≤ 4. Find (a) the displacement and (b) the total distance traveled.

Water flows into a tank at a rate of R(t) = 200 - 4t² gallons per minute. At time t = 0, the tank holds 500 gallons. (a) How much water enters the tank during the first 5 minutes? (b) How much water is in the tank at t = 5?
examples.solution: (a) Net water in = ∫₀⁵ (200 - 4t²) dt = [200t - (4t³/3)]₀⁵ = 1000 - 500/3 = 3000/3 - 500/3 = 2500/3 ≈ 833.3 gallons. (b) Amount at t = 5: 500 + 2500/3 = 1500/3 + 2500/3 = 4000/3 ≈ 1333.3 gallons. By the net change theorem, the total amount equals the initial amount plus the integral of the rate.

examples.problem: A particle's velocity is v(t) = 3cos(t) m/s and its position at t = 0 is s(0) = 2 m. Find the position at t = π and the total distance traveled on [0, π].
examples.solution: Position: s(π) = s(0) + ∫₀π 3cos(t) dt = 2 + [3sin(t)]₀π = 2 + (0 - 0) = 2 m. Displacement is 0 — the particle returns to its starting position. Total distance: v(t) = 3cos(t) = 0 at t = π/2. v > 0 on [0, π/2], v < 0 on [π/2, π]. Distance = ∫₀^(π/2) 3cos(t) dt + ∫_(π/2)^π |3cos(t)| dt = [3sin(t)]₀^(π/2) + [-3sin(t)]_(π/2)^π = 3 + 3 = 6 m.

problems.problem: Find the average value of f(x) = 6x - x² on [0, 6] and find all values c in (0, 6) where f(c) equals the average value.
hints: Use f_avg = (1/(b-a)) ∫ₐᵇ f(x) dx with a=0, b=6
Set 6c - c² = f_avg and solve the quadratic

problems.problem: A particle moves with velocity v(t) = t - 3 for 0 ≤ t ≤ 5. Find the displacement and total distance traveled.
hints: Split and take absolute values for total distance

problems.problem: Oil leaks from a tanker at a rate of r(t) = 75e^(-0.03t) gallons per hour. How many gallons leak during the first 10 hours? What is the average rate of leakage over [0, 10]?

scaffold.title: Area Between Curves
scaffold.content: The area between two curves extends the definite integral from 'area under a curve' to 'area between two boundaries.' The key principle: integrate (top function minus bottom function) with respect to x, or (right function minus left function) with respect to y. Correctly identifying the bounds and which curve is on top is the essential setup skill.
keyPoints: Area = ∫ₐᵇ [f(x) - g(x)] dx where f(x) ≥ g(x) on [a, b] (top minus bottom)
Finding bounds: set f(x) = g(x) to find intersection points. These are typically the limits of integration.
If curves cross: split the integral at the crossing point. On each sub-interval, determine which is on top.
Integrating with respect to y: Area = ∫_c^d [R(y) - L(y)] dy where R is the right curve and L is the left curve
When to use dy: when the region is more naturally bounded by functions of y, or when horizontal slicing avoids splitting
Common AP error: setting up ∫(f - g) when g > f yields a negative answer. Always verify which curve is on top.

examples.problem: Find the area enclosed between y = x² and y = x + 2.
Find the area between x = y² and x = 2 - y² using integration with respect to y.
examples.solution: Find intersections: y² = 2 - y² → 2y² = 2 → y² = 1 → y = ±1. For -1 ≤ y ≤ 1, the right curve is x = 2 - y² and the left curve is x = y². Area = ∫₋₁¹ [(2 - y²) - y²] dy = ∫₋₁¹ (2 - 2y²) dy = [2y - 2y³/3]₋₁¹ = (2 - 2/3) - (-2 + 2/3) = 4/3 + 4/3 = 8/3.

examples.problem: Find the area between y = sin(x) and y = cos(x) on [0, π/2].

scaffold.title: Volume by Cross-Sections
scaffold.content: When a solid has a known cross-sectional shape perpendicular to an axis, its volume is found by integrating the cross-sectional area. The key is expressing the area A(x) (or A(y)) in terms of the integration variable, using the geometric formula for the given shape and identifying the dimension of each cross-section from the bounding curves.
keyPoints: General formula: V = ∫ₐᵇ A(x) dx, where A(x) is the area of the cross-section at position x
Square cross-sections: if the side length is s(x), then A(x) = [s(x)]²
Semicircular cross-sections: if the diameter is d(x), then A(x) = (π/2)(d(x)/2)² = πd(x)²/8
Equilateral triangle cross-sections: if the side is s(x), then A(x) = (√3/4)[s(x)]²
The side/diameter is typically the distance between two curves: s(x) = f(x) - g(x)
Perpendicular to x-axis: integrate with respect to x. Perpendicular to y-axis: integrate with respect to y.

examples.problem: A solid has a base bounded by y = √x and y = 0 from x = 0 to x = 4. Cross-sections perpendicular to the x-axis are squares. Find the volume.
examples.solution: The side of each square is s(x) = √x - 0 = √x. Area of cross-section: A(x) = (√x)² = x. Volume = ∫₀⁴ x dx = [x²/2]₀⁴ = 16/2 = 8.

examples.problem: A solid has a base bounded by y = 1 - x² and y = 0 (the region above the x-axis). Cross-sections perpendicular to the x-axis are semicircles with diameter running from y = 0 to y = 1 - x². Find the volume.
examples.solution: Base region: 1 - x² ≥ 0 → -1 ≤ x ≤ 1. Diameter: d(x) = 1 - x². Radius: r(x) = (1-x²)/2. Area: A(x) = (1/2)π[(1-x²)/2]² = π(1-x²)²/8. Volume = (π/8) ∫₋₁¹ (1-x²)² dx. Expand: (1-x²)² = 1 - 2x² + x⁴. By symmetry: (π/8)·2 ∫₀¹ (1 - 2x² + x⁴) dx = (π/4)[x - 2x³/3 + x⁵/5]₀¹ = (π/4)(1 - 2/3 + 1/5) = (π/4)(8/15) = 2π/15.

scaffold.title: Volume by Disk & Washer Methods
scaffold.content: When a region is revolved around an axis (or a line), the resulting solid of revolution has circular cross-sections. The disk method handles solids with no hole; the washer method handles solids with a hole (an inner boundary). The critical skill is correctly identifying the outer radius R and inner radius r relative to the axis of revolution.
keyPoints: Disk method (no hole): V = π ∫ₐᵇ [R(x)]² dx, where R(x) is the distance from the curve to the axis of revolution
Washer method (hole): V = π ∫ₐᵇ ([R(x)]² - [r(x)]²) dx, where R = outer radius, r = inner radius
Revolving around x-axis: R and r are vertical distances (y-values or differences of y-values)
Revolving around y-axis: rewrite as x = g(y) and integrate with respect to y, or use shell method (BC only for AP AB)
Revolving around y = k (non-axis line): R(x) = |f(x) - k| for outer, r(x) = |g(x) - k| for inner
Revolving around x = k: R(y) = |g(y) - k| for outer, r(y) = |h(y) - k| for inner; integrate dy
Common AP error: writing R² - r² as (R - r)². They are NOT the same. Always square each radius separately.

scaffold.title: Volume by Disk & Washer — Worked Examples

examples.problem: Find the volume of the solid formed by revolving y = √x from x = 0 to x = 4 about the x-axis.
examples.solution: Disk method: R(x) = √x (distance from curve to x-axis). V = π ∫₀⁴ (√x)² dx = π ∫₀⁴ x dx = π[x²/2]₀⁴ = π(8) = 8π.

examples.problem: Find the volume of the solid formed by revolving the region between y = x² and y = √x about the x-axis.
examples.solution: Intersections: x² = √x → x⁴ = x → x(x³ - 1) = 0 → x = 0, 1. On [0,1]: √x ≥ x² (outer curve). Washer method: R(x) = √x, r(x) = x². V = π ∫₀¹ [(√x)² - (x²)²] dx = π ∫₀¹ (x - x⁴) dx = π[x²/2 - x⁵/5]₀¹ = π(1/2 - 1/5) = π(3/10) = 3π/10.

examples.problem: Find the volume of the solid formed by revolving the region bounded by y = x and y = x² about the line y = 2.
examples.solution: Intersections: x = x² → x² - x = 0 → x(x-1) = 0 → x = 0, 1. On [0, 1]: x ≥ x² so y = x is on top (closer to y = 2 from below, but we measure from the axis). Since y = 2 is above both curves on [0, 1]: Outer radius R(x) = 2 - x² (distance from axis to farther curve from axis). Inner radius r(x) = 2 - x (distance from axis to closer curve to axis). V = π ∫₀¹ [(2 - x²)² - (2 - x)²] dx. Expand: (2-x²)² = 4 - 4x² + x⁴; (2-x)² = 4 - 4x + x². Difference: -4x² + x⁴ + 4x - x² = x⁴ - 5x² + 4x. V = π ∫₀¹ (x⁴ - 5x² + 4x) dx = π[x⁵/5 - 5x³/3 + 2x²]₀¹ = π(1/5 - 5/3 + 2) = π(3/15 - 25/15 + 30/15) = 8π/15.

problems.problem: Find the area enclosed by y = x³ - x and y = 3x. Sketch the region first.
hints: Test which is on top on each sub-interval: at x = 1, 3x = 3 > 1³ - 1 = 0
The curves cross at x = 0, so you need two integrals (or use symmetry)
problems.answer: On [-2, 0]: x³ - x ≥ 3x (test x = -1: -1+1 = 0 > -3). On [0, 2]: 3x ≥ x³ - x. By odd symmetry, both integrals are equal. Area = 2 ∫₀² [3x - (x³ - x)] dx = 2 ∫₀² (4x - x³) dx = 2[2x² - x⁴/4]₀² = 2(8 - 4) = 8.

problems.problem: A solid has a base bounded by the circle x² + y² = 9. Cross-sections perpendicular to the x-axis are equilateral triangles. Find the volume.
hints: From the circle: y = ±√(9 - x²). Side length s(x) = 2√(9 - x²)

problems.problem: Find the volume of the solid formed by revolving the region bounded by y = eˣ, y = 1, and x = ln 3 about the x-axis.
hints: Sketch: eˣ ≥ 1 for x ≥ 0. Region from x = 0 to x = ln 3 between y = eˣ (top) and y = 1 (bottom)
problems.answer: Bounds: eˣ = 1 at x = 0, and x = ln 3. V = π ∫₀^(ln3) [(eˣ)² - 1²] dx = π ∫₀^(ln3) (e²ˣ - 1) dx = π[e²ˣ/2 - x]₀^(ln3) = π[(e^(2ln3))/2 - ln 3 - 1/2 + 0] = π[(9/2) - ln 3 - 1/2] = π(4 - ln 3).

problems.problem: Find the volume of the solid formed by revolving y = 4 - x² (for y ≥ 0) about the line y = -1.
hints: 4 - x² = 0 → x = ±2. Region from x = -2 to x = 2 above x-axis
Revolving around y = -1 (below the region). Outer radius = (4 - x²) - (-1) = 5 - x²
Inner radius = 0 - (-1) = 1 (from x-axis to the line y = -1)

problems.problem: Find the average value of g(x) = sin(x) on [0, π]. Then find the value c in (0, π) guaranteed by the MVT for Integrals where g(c) = g_avg.
problems.answer: g_avg = (1/π) ∫₀π sin(x) dx = (1/π)[-cos(x)]₀π = (1/π)(1 + 1) = 2/π. Solve sin(c) = 2/π → c = arcsin(2/π) ≈ 0.690. Since 2/π ≈ 0.637 < 1, c exists in (0, π).

problems.problem: A particle moves along a line with velocity v(t) = sin(πt) - 1/2 for 0 ≤ t ≤ 2. Find the displacement and the total distance traveled.
Find the area of the region enclosed by y = x² - 2x and y = -x² + 4.
A solid has a base bounded by y = x and y = x² (for 0 ≤ x ≤ 1). Cross-sections perpendicular to the x-axis are squares with sides running from y = x² to y = x. Find the volume.
problems.answer: Side length: s(x) = x - x². Area: A(x) = (x - x²)² = x² - 2x³ + x⁴. Volume = ∫₀¹ (x² - 2x³ + x⁴) dx = [x³/3 - x⁴/2 + x⁵/5]₀¹ = 1/3 - 1/2 + 1/5 = (10 - 15 + 6)/30 = 1/30.

problems.problem: Find the volume of the solid formed by revolving the region bounded by y = x² and y = 4 about (a) the x-axis, and (b) the line x = 3.
problems.answer: (a) Intersections: x² = 4 → x = ±2. Washer: R = 4, r = x². V = π ∫₋₂² (16 - x⁴) dx = 2π ∫₀² (16 - x⁴) dx = 2π[16x - x⁵/5]₀² = 2π(32 - 32/5) = 2π(128/5) = 256π/5. (b) Rewrite as x = √y (right half by symmetry, then double for both sides). Using washers with respect to y from y = 0 to y = 4: R(y) = 3 - (-√y) = 3 + √y, r(y) = 3 - √y. V = π ∫₀⁴ [(3+√y)² - (3-√y)²] dx. Expand: (3+√y)² - (3-√y)² = 12√y. V = π ∫₀⁴ 12√y dy = 12π[2y^(3/2)/3]₀⁴ = 12π(16/3) = 64π.

problems.problem: (FRQ-style) Water flows into a reservoir at a rate of R(t) = 100e^(-0.1t) cubic feet per hour and flows out at a constant rate of 40 cubic feet per hour. At t = 0, the reservoir holds 800 cubic feet. (a) Is the amount of water increasing or decreasing at t = 5? (b) Find the average rate of net inflow on [0, 10]. (c) At what time t does the reservoir reach its maximum volume? (d) What is the maximum volume?

answerKeys.motion-trig-velocity: s(π) = 2 m. Displacement = 0. Total distance = 6 m.
answerKeys.ip-frq-reservoir: (a) Increasing (net rate ≈ 20.65). (b) Avg ≈ 23.21 ft³/hr. (c) t = 10ln(2.5) ≈ 9.16 hr. (d) V_max ≈ 1033.5 ft³.
